comments.text:
Actually no... they can't. The burning sensation is just capsaicin 
attaching to pain receptors and giving you a perceived pain that is more 
intense the more capsaicin the pepper has. Casein in milk products breaks 
down the capsaicin. High fat content is better than low fat content. I find 
that full fat greek yogurt works the best because with milk you swish 
around the capsaicin in your mouth. With superhots, such as the Trinidad 
Scorpion Moruga or the new #1 pepper, the Carolina Reaper, milk won't do 
jack squat, matter of fact, it'll make the burn WORSE.

+TLI-Inferno You're kind of right, but for the wrong reason. Capsaicin is 
the molecule which makes peppers hot. Capsaicin is very hydrophobic and 
lipophilic meaning it does not dissolve well in water but dissolves well in 
lipids(ie fats).
The reason  Milk, cream, ice cream, sour cream, cheese work is not because 
they are basic but because they contain fats which bind to the capsaicin
comments.author: jd236236

comments.text:
+Rita Britanica Scoville, not degrees. Scoville is the measure of pure 
capsaicin. Degrees is the measure of temperature. If it was 
15,000,000-16,000,000 degrees, no-one in that area of the world would be 
alive. One, tiny drop would me over a hundred times hotter than the sun. So 
yeah, you wouldn't be able to eat it as you would probably die from looking 
in its direction, lol. Also, pure capsaicin is edible. They have made 
sauces that is simply pure capsaicin measuring at 16,000,000 scoville and 
you can eat it, it's just advised not to try more than two drops for the 
fear of stomach problems. Resiniferatoxin is what you're probably thinking 
of as it is highly toxic. Resinferatoxin is the spiciest thing found thus 
far measuring at 16,000,000,000 scoville, many time spicier than pure 
capsaicin.

I just read up on hiccup after your question and found something really 
interesting:

Apparently there is no explanation as to why it occurs and what its purpose 
even is. It just happens. And the area of the brain that causes the 
respiratory system to hiccup is the same brain area that, in fish and other 
sea creatures, controls the breathing with gills.

That's amazing. So my uninformed guess is that hiccup is just a reflex that 
is very important in fish brains but in the human brain somehow only 
triggers when... our body hates us for what we just put into it through our 
mouth? Crazy.

comments.text:
Edit: That's fair, I didn't see your comment about not seeing my comment, 
which lead to me making *this* comment. So I say we're even. /edit

We don't use 100% of our brains at all times, no. The amount of energy 
consumption that would require would be detrimental to survival, and would 
provide no real, tangible benefits, as the majority of the brain isn't used 
for thought/higher functions. We do, however, utilize 100% of our brain.

I don't think it's fair to say that we don't use 100% of our brains just 
because at any given moment, some parts aren't active due to lack of 
necessity. As long as every part of the brain is utilized at some point 
(which it is) I think it's perfectly reasonable to say we use 100% of our 
brains.

him stupid and ignorant should probably look things up before you start 
acting smug or superior, because, uh...he's more or less completely right.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ten_percent_of_brain_myth

Sure, there is only a small percentage used for active, conscious thought 
or memory access/retention but we do utilize every part of the brain. Some 
more often than others, but every part is utilized, much of it to 
control/regulate passive bodily functions.

So, seriously, if you're going to scoff at somebody you should really try 
to make sure you're right first.
